item.title: The Laws of Simplicity
item.description:
The Laws of Simplicity

On the one hand, you want a product or service to be easy to use; on the other hand you want it to do everything that a person might want it to do. The process of reaching an ideal state of simplicity can be truly complex, so allow me to simplify it for you.

item.title: The Truth About 'Performance Improvement Plans'
item.description:
The Truth About 'Performance Improvement Plans'

What's the story with Performance Improvement Plans? Here's the scoop.

item.title: Hacking The Career: What Organizations Should Do
item.description:
Hacking The Career: What Organizations Should Do

One of the most disruptive changes we've seen in business over the last decade is the end of the traditional "career." People used to join companies for life: We would look for a great company when we got out of school, join the new-hire development program, pay our dues working up [...]

item.title: Why Successful People Spend 10 Hours a Week Just Thinking
item.description:
Why Successful People Spend 10 Hours a Week Just Thinking

Warren Buffett, the CEO of the fourth largest company in the country, isn't as busy as you are. By his own estimate, he has spent 80% of his career reading and thinking. "That's what created [one of the] world's most successful business records in history.

item.title: 5 Signs Your Company's Culture Is Dying
item.description:
5 Signs Your Company's Culture Is Dying

Right now, U.S. companies are struggling to find people they need for their open positions. Two main factors are driving the current talent crisis in America today: The Age Curve is creating a shortage of skilled workers. The Gig Economy is resulting in an increase in job hopping.

item.title: Pioneers, Settlers and Town Planners
item.description:
Pioneers, Settlers and Town Planners

After posting about the composition of multidisciplinary teams, (friend of ODF) Mike Baxter sent me a link to Simon Wardly's post on Pioneers, Settlers, and Town Planners, which describies a unique combination of characteristics needed to bring products and services to life. The concept, says Simon, is adapted from Robert X.

item.title: 5 Books That Will Inspire You To Never Give Up On Your Dreams
item.description:
5 Books That Will Inspire You To Never Give Up On Your Dreams

I am an avid reader. I read because there is so much incredible material out there to learn from, but I also read to stay inspired. In the same way movies and YouTube montages and podcasts inspire, books can have a tremendous impact on the way we see the world--and what we believe is "achievable."

item.title: Species of Organizations
item.description:
Species of Organizations

14 April 2016 There are species of organizations just as there are species of animals. Don't mix them up. A bear is not a beaver; one winters in caves, the other in wooden structures they build for themselves. Hospitals are not factories; advertising agencies are not fast food companies.

item.title: The future of business is that the customer is the labor and the capital
item.description:
The future of business is that the customer is the labor and the capital

There is a common misunderstanding about the coming automated economy that may destroy us all. Most people in business and finance (and most people, frankly) think that the new economy (of artificial intelligence and autonomous machines) is like the old economy: satisfying customers' needs for products and services. That's just not so.

item.title: World's biggest startup? Samsung to reform corporate culture
item.description:
World's biggest startup? Samsung to reform corporate culture

SEOUL (By Se Young Lee, Reuters) - Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, the world's biggest maker of smartphones and memory chips, announced on Thursday that it plans to adopt a corporate culture akin to a startup, seeking to become more nimble as growth slows.
